content.description:
The right route on the right slab (directions not a description). Start the same as Stampede but head right at the second bolt and enjoy the juggy holds up the slab that seems steeper than you think.

The top has one last fun challenge.

The holds are a bit smaller than on Stampede which is why it is rated a bit harder.

The left route on the right slab. Start the same as W.T.T.J. but head left when you clip the second bolt. Jug city follows! Fun Fun Fun! (Tristan never repeats routes and he has done this several times. That should tell you how much fun it is)
Similar to Call of the Wild, but just slightly more difficult. Climb past 5 bolts on good pockets and jugs to the chains. The start is still a bit dirty.
content.location: On the low-angled, pocketed slab on the left side of the Wild. This climb is directly right of Call of the Wild, and left of the steep corner/arete that is Chupacabra.

content.description:
This route climbs the corner on the right side of the upper slab on the right side of the Wild.

I would recommend that only experienced trad leaders lead this route. It's not hard and the protection is pretty good, but still, you've got to have confidence in placing gear in limestone. We don't like to bolt cracks, that's why we left it as a trad route. If you don't have trad gear, just toprope the thing, but don't bolt the crack.
content.protection:
A couple slings (I slung the detached pillar with a shoulder-length sling), medium cams (I used red and gold Camalots), a quickdraw for the one bolt in the middle of the route. Maybe some medium-large nuts. Chains on top.

You can toprope this route by first climbing either Welcome to the Jungle or Stampede and just reaching over to the chains of this route. The anchors are a few feet apart.
content.location: The obvious corner to the right of Welcome to the Jungle. There is one bolt in the middle of the route where the crack doesn't take any gear.

content.description:
This is a great little crack! Awesome for beginner leaders. You don't need to jam at all, as there are holds everywhere on the sides of the crack.

The crack, especially the bottom part, is still pretty dirty, but should clean up with more ascents.
content.protection: Medium to large pieces to Call of the Wild's anchors.
content.location: The obvious corner crack left of Call of the Wild and right of Congo.

content.description: The first route you encounter (left side) and a real shorty. Was bolted as a teaching route. Great for beginning leaders. Still, it's not a bad climb.

Follows a steep section on the left side of the slabs. The start can be a bit tricky but look for nice left facing jugs here and there. A big reach after clipping the second bolt and it is basically done.

**This route can also be done on the right side of the bolts using some pretty good pockets (even though this was not the original line. It seems that someone went ahead and cleaned out all the dirty pockets). This method of doing the route is not harder than 5.8.

This is a great climb! Climb past a couple bolts to a steeper headwall section. Pull past this section on lots of fun pulling on great jugs. That's the crux, but it's also the best part of the route. (Stay left if you want the 5.10 experience; going right makes it easier). After that, the route slabs out a bit up to the chains.
content.location: The steep prow/corner that is between the left slab (the section of wall that has Call of the Wild and Serengeti on it) and the right slab (the section of wall with Stampede and Welcome to the Jungle on it). Access it from the main landing (the landing under the slab routes on the left side of the Wild).

content.description: This is a very unique route. There's nothing else like it in Rock Canyon, or even American Fork. Just about every hold is a huge, juggy pocket. The pockets are awesome! Also, this route has the world's greatest undercling. Enjoy!
content.location: The left-most of the two obvious, pocketed slab routes on the right side of the Wild. Just right of the corner crack that is Heart of Darkness.

content.description:
Because it's there. I had to climb it because... It's climbable. But it's not really worth doing unless you want another tick. It's the worst route on the wall.

Start right behind the little pine tree on the left side of the main lending. Climb up the right side of the leaning pillar, up a small corner. There are still some loose blocks in the there, so be careful. When the corner ends, just continue up to Congo's anchors.
content.protection: Medium-sized pieces to Congo's anchors. I even tied off a couple small bushes that probably wouldn't hold a fall...
content.location: This route is left of Congo and right of Gazelle. It starts in a corner just behind the pine tree.
